An Act for vesting Part of the settled Estates of Su~ fannah Harriott Eyre, the Wife of William Eyret Esquire, in Trustees, to be sold, and for applying Part of the Purchase-Money in paying off Incumbrances and Charges upon such Estates, and for laying out the Residue of the Purchase-Monies in the Purchase of other Estates, to be settled to the former Uses. [22d July 1S06.]

An A(fl for enabling a married Person to hold and enjoy the Office of Warden of Wadhatn College, in the University of Oxford. [22d July 1.B06.J

WHEREAS by the Statutes of Wadham College, in the Univerfitv of Oxford, given to the said College by the Founder thereof, it is ordained that the Warden of the said College shall be chosen out of those who are or have been Fellows of the said College, and have honourably departed from it; and also that the Warden of the said College shall, at the Time of hrs Election to the Office of Warden, be, and whilst he shall be Warden of the said College, continue to be a Bachelor and unmarried ; and also that the said Warden shall take an Oath that he hath not contracted, not will enter into any Contraft of Matrimony so long as he shall be Warden of the said College: And whereas in the present State of Society it is reasonable and fit, and likely to conduce to the Benefit of the said College, that a married Person, otherwise duly qualified, shall, notwithstanding the said Statutes, be capable of being elected into and to hold and enjoy the said Office of Warden of the said College, and that every Warden of the said College shall after his Election into and during his Continuance in the said Office be allowed to marry and continue such Warden, notwithstanding his Marriage and the said Statutes; may it please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, [t.oc. & Per.] 33 Y in

in this present Parliament act’embled, and by the Authority of the same, That from and after the passing of this Act, so much of the Statutes of the said College as ordains that the Warden of the said College shall at the Time of his Election to the Office of Warden be, and whilst he shall be Warden of the said College continue to be, a Bachelor and unmarried ; and also so much of the said Statutes as ordains that the said Warden shall take an Oath that he hath nor contracted, nor will enter into any Contract of Matrimony so long as he shall be Warden of the said College, shall be and the fame are hereby declared to be null and void to all Intents and Purposes; any Thing in the said_Statutes contained to the contrary thereof notwithstanding.

II. And be it further enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That from and after the passing of this Act all and every such Clause, Matter, and Thing in the said Statutes of the said College contained, ns imposes any Restraint on the Fellows of the said College from electing a married Man (otherwise duly qualified) to the Office of Warden or Head of the said College, or from permitting the Warden or Head of the said College, after his Election to the said Office of Warden or Head, to marry, shall be and the fame are hereby declared to be null and void to all Intents and Purposes whatsoever; any Thing in the said Statutes contained, or any Law or Statute to the contrary notwithstanding.

III. And be it further enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That from and after the passing of this Act so much of the Oath directed to be taken by the Warden or Head of the said College on his Election to the said Office of Warden or Head of the said College, as declares that such Warden or Head hath not contracted nor wilt enter into any Contract of Matrimony so long as he shall be Warden or Head of the said College, and also so much of such Oath as tends in any Manner to restrain such Warden or Head from marrying or contracting Matrimony, and also the reading, at the Time of the Nomination and Election of such Warden or Head, osso much of the said Statutes of the said College as relates to the said Warden or Head of the said College not marrying or contracting Matrimony, shall be omitted.

IV. And be it further enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That from and after the passing of this Act it shall be lawful for every Warden or Head of the said College to marry, and to continue such Warden or Head in the same Manner to all Intents and Purposes, as before the passing of this Act he would have been if h? had not been married ; and also for any Person, though married or contracted in Matrimony, who shall be in all other RefpeCts duly qualified, to be elected into, and to accept of and hold and enjoy the Office of Warden or Head of the said College; such Scatutes of the said College or any other Law or Statute, Matter'or Thing, to the contrary notwithstanding.

V. And be it further enacted by the Authority |aforesaid, That from and after the passing of this Act, it shall be lawful for the Fellows of the said Culiege to nominate and elect any Person who is married or con, traded in Matrimony to be such Warden or Head of the said College, provided the Person so to be nominated and elected such Warden or Head shall in every other Respect be duly qualified to be nujninated and

VI. And be it further enacted, by the Authority aforesaid, That nothing in this Act contained shall alter, annul, or make void, any sratutSro other Parts of the said Statutes of the said College not hereby annulled ; be annulled and that the said Warden, Fellows, and Scholars of the said College by'thjsAfr* shall have, hold, and enjoy all Estates, Rights, Privileges, Benefits, and annulled. Emoluments belonging to the said College, in the same Manner to all

Intents and Purposes, as they might have held and enjoyed the fame, if this Act had not been made ; any Thing herein, or in the said Statutes of the said College contained, or any Law or Custom to the contrary notwithstanding.

VII. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be printed by the Evidence* Printer to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, and a Copy thereof, so printed, shall be admitted as Evidence thereof by all Judges, Justices,

and others.
